Configuration Management on EC2 Using Ansible

05 May 2016 • Automation • AWS • Ops

Introduction

Ansible is one of the easiest Configuration Management tools to get started with due to its client-less architecture. Ansible is written in Python and uses YAML for is configuration files which is a simple and human-readable syntax. One of the most important features of Ansible is its idempotency which meansÂ changes are only made when required and ignored otherwise.Â ThisÂ preventsÂ the possibility of inconsistency in your infrastructure.

Installation

  1. The easiest and recommended way of installing is from the package repositories. Simply run: <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
  2. sudo apt-get install ansible 
    3. </ul>
  3. To test the installation, run the following. If you get a prompt asking for the SSH password, it indicates that the installation was successful. <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
  4. ansible all -m ping --ask-pass 
    5. </ul>
  5. Open the file /etc/ansible/hosts and add the IPsÂ of your servers in it. For example, you can addÂ EC2 instance public IP or you can add theÂ private IP if your control machine is the sameÂ VPC as the servers. The control machine as the name indicates is the machine which will be sending the commands to your servers.
  6. To test if the control machine is able to reach the servers, run the pingÂ command. Key-based authentication is encouraged over passwords. use the --private-key flag to specify the path to your keyfile. If successful, it will return a JSON response containing the string âsuccessâ. <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
  7. ansible all -m ping --private-key ~/path/to/key -u ubuntu 
    8. </ul>
  8. To log in as root, add the become flag (-b) <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
  9. ansible all -m ping --private-key ~/path/to/key -u ubuntu -b 
    10. </ul>
  10. Test the configuration further by running a live command on the nodes <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
  11. ansible all -a "/bin/echo skywide" --private-key ~/path/to/key -u ubuntu 
    12. </ul>
  12. If youâd like to have a fully automated and unattended setup, it would be wise to disable the host key checking feature. This feature when enabled will prompt for confirmation of the key the first time Ansible tries to log into the server. Disabling host key checking howeverÂ hasÂ someÂ implications and you might want to fully understand them beforeÂ disabling the host check.Â Inside /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg, edit the following <ul style="list-style-type: disc;">
  13. host_key_checking = False 
    14. </ul>
  14. This way, youÂ are able to successfully run commands on your nodes. However, Ansible goesÂ far beyond running simple commands on your nodes. To make the most of it,Â we need to make use of playbooks.

Components

  1. Inventory <ul style="list-style-type: square;">
  2. The inventory file is nothing but a file containing the list of servers you want to configure. This file by default exists at /etc/ansible/hosts. It is also possible to use multipleÂ inventory files. 
    3. </ul>
  3. Dynamic Inventory <ul style="list-style-type: square;">
  4. A Dynamic Inventory is when the inventory files are stored in a different system. For example, the files can be stored on a cloud storage provider, LDAP or other such storage solutions. 
    5. </ul>
  5. Patterns <ul style="list-style-type: square;">
  6. The hosts that are specified in an inventory file can be grouped into categories like “web servers” and “db servers” by using the appropriate syntax. A Pattern refers to a set of groups (which are a set of hosts). Take for example, ansible all -m ping. Here “all” refers to all hosts. Whereas in ansible webservers -m ping,Â the command will only work on the hosts in the group “webservers” as defined in the inventory file. 
    7. </ul>
  7. Variables <ul style="list-style-type: square;">
  8. Variables, as the name suggests, are values that are used when you are working on systems that require varied configuration. Variables can be something like a port number or a private IP address. Variables can be defined either in Inventory files or Playbooks.
  9. Example 
    - hosts: webservers
  vars:
    http_port: 80

    Here http_port is a variable.</li> </ul> </li>

  10. Ad-Hoc Commands
    • Ad-Hoc Commands are used to perform quick tasks that you don’t want to write an entire playbook for. Take the analogy of running a command through shell (ad-hoc command) and running it through a bash script (playbook).Â ansible all -m ping is an example of a ad-hoc command.
  11. Playbooks
      • A playbook is a file containing instructions. The following playbook will install Apache web server on your nodes.

    </li>

  12. To run the playbook, use the following command
    • ansible-playbook skywide.yaml --private-key ~/path/to/key.pem
    • If you want to avoid specifying the path to the key file every time, modify the file /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg and setÂ the path in the variable private_key_file
    13. </ol>

The following is a bare-minimum CloudFormation templateÂ to launch an EC2 instance. Itâs bare-minimum in the sense that only theÂ Parameters and Resources which are absolutely necessaryÂ are part of the template.

This templateÂ can alsoÂ execute a bash script provided as User Data to the EC2 instance. The User Data can be a set of directives that will be executed only once during the first boot cycle of the instance. This feature can be usedÂ when you need to say launchÂ several instances with the Apache web serverÂ installed on them. To do this you would simply supply the command apt-get installÂ apache2 as user-data. There is no need to add sudo keyword to the command as the script will be run with root privileges.

In the above template, the custom script updates the list of packages (apt-get update) and installs Apache (apt-get install apache2). You can add/remove commands as required. Be sure to put them inside double quotes and each command should be on a new line.
